I also wanted to let you know that I EMAILED you my assignment and it is completed.

This is a great example of making the most of remote learning. Not only is Krayten learning about and practicing a skill, 3D printing, that he can use in his future, he is also helping our community in this time of need.

Here are five small changes you can make to be happier. They are all free AND ALL POSSIBLE WHILE STAYING AT HOME!

1. Gratitude

Taking the time to feel grateful for what you have puts you in a positive state of mind. "Gratitude functions to nurture social relationships through its encouragement of reciprocal, pro-social behavior between a benefactor and recipient."

2. Journaling

"Writing about emotional experiences is associated with a host of positive outcomes."

3. Exercise

"16 weeks of aerobic exercise training was comparable to that of standard pharmacotherapy." So get off the meds, and get moving!

4. Meditation

"In her brilliant book, Mindset, Dweck shows how success in school, work, sports, the arts, and almost every area of human endeavor can be dramatically influenced by how we approach our goals."

5. Random Acts of Kindness

"Short-term increases in happiness were found, but only for participants who practiced the five acts of kindness all in a single day."

In the meantime, SRO Brewer and Oakland Chief of Police Sanders were able to determine the staff member had accidentally called the family member and neither the staff member nor the school were in any harm. Coles County dispatch was called and the 911 call was cancelled.

In the case of an actual emergency, we will always do our best to communicate with with the community in a timely fashion.

Mrs. Welch's Anatomy class is studying skin and conducted a lab discovering the different types of fingerprints.

School Resource Officer Brewer brought in fingerprint dust and supplies to lift prints off several objects. Students made comparisons of prints lifted with their own fingerprints. Students learned that a fingerprint is an individual characteristic-no two people have the same exact fingerprint pattern and that patterns remain unchanged for life

This was a fun lab in which everyone learned the types of prints and what their own prints are. In the US, the most common pattern is the loop-60%, the whorl-35% and the arch-5%.

Next up, Anatomy students will be looking at the individual minutiae on a print and then identify the minutiae on their own prints they have made.
